questions.text: A pediatric patient presents with a completely displaced supracondylar fracture of the humerus, confirmed on X-ray. Which classification is used for this type of fracture, and what is its stage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gartland type 3 refers to a completely displaced supracondylar fracture of the humerus in children, with no cortical contact, and is the most unstable type.

  • The Gartland classification is the most widely used system for categorizing supracondylar fractures of the humerus in children, which are among the most common pediatric elbow fractures.
  • Gartland Type 3 fractures are unstable, often with soft tissue swelling and risk of neurovascular injury. Prompt orthopedic management is necessary.

Explanation of other options:

Gartland 2 (Option B): Indicates partial displacement with intact posterior hinge-less severe than type 3.

Salter-Harris 3 (Option C): Involves a fracture through the physis and epiphysis, extending into the joint, used for physeal injuries, not supracondylar fractures.

Salter-Harris 2 (Option D): Fracture through the physis and metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis, again, unrelated to supracondylar fractures.

questions.text: An 8-year-old male child presents with fever and tenderness in the left lower limb. The limb is warm to the touch, and ESR is raised. An X-ray reveals periosteal elevation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fever, localized warmth, raised ESR, and periosteal elevation on X-ray are classic indicators of acute osteomyelitis.

  • Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, commonly caused by pyogenic bacteria in children.
  • caused by pyogenic bacteria in children. The metaphysis of long bones is the usual site due to its rich vascular supply and sluggish blood flow, which predisposes to bacterial seeding.
  • Clinically, it presents with fever, localized pain, warmth, tenderness, and systemic signs of infection.
  • Raised ESR and CRP are common laboratory findings. On radiography, periosteal elevation appears by 7-10 days due to subperiosteal abscess formation.
  • Early radiographs may be normal, so MRI is more sensitive in the early phase (within 24 hours) as it can detect bone marrow edema.
  • Confirmation of diagnosis is through aspiration and culture of the infected site.

Explanation of other options:

Ewing sarcoma (Option A): A malignant small round cell tumor seen in children and adolescents; presents with fever, pain, and swelling but is less likely to show acute signs of infection like warmth and raised ESR early. Onion-skin periosteal reaction is more characteristic.

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Malignant bone tumor of adolescence; typically presents with pain and swelling. X-ray shows sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle-not just simple periosteal elevation.

Giant Cell Tumor (Option D): Benign, locally aggressive tumor seen in skeletally mature individuals (usually after closure of epiphyses); rare in children and not associated with fever or signs of infection.

questions.text: Identify the orthopedic implant shown in the image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The implant shown is a Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS), commonly used for intertrochanteric fractures of the femur.

  • The Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) is a sliding screw-plate system used to manage stable intertrochanteric femur fractures, especially in elderly patients.
  • Components:
    • A large lag screw: Inserted into the femoral neck and head.
    • A side plate with barrel: Fixed along the lateral femoral cortex with cortical screws.
  • The "dynamic" mechanism allows for controlled collapse at the fracture site during weight-bearing, which promotes healing by compression.
  • Indications:
    • Stable intertrochanteric fractures (AO/OTA 31-A1 and some A2 fractures)
    • Osteoporotic bone in elderly patients
  • Advantages:
    • Allows for controlled impaction at the fracture site
    • Simple and effective in appropriate fracture patterns

Explanation of other options:

Adynamic Hip Screw (Option B): Not a recognized term in orthopedics-nonexistent terminology.

Condylar Hip Screw (Option C): Used for distal femur (condylar) fractures, not for intertrochanteric fractures.

Intramedullary Nail (Option D): While proximal femoral nails can treat intertrochanteric fractures, the implant in the image is extramedullary, not an intramedullary nail.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557514/

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5th metatarsal fracture. For how many days he/she would have to wear a cast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 5th metatarsal fracture typically requires casting for 6-8 weeks to ensure adequate healing and prevent complications like non-union.

  • The 5th metatarsal, especially the proximal portion, is prone to fractures, commonly referred to as Jones fractures when they occur at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction.
  • This region has relatively poor blood supply, so adequate immobilization is crucial to allow proper healing.
  • The standard management involves non-weight-bearing immobilization in a cast or walking boot for 6-8 weeks.
  • Healing is monitored with follow-up radiographs.
  • Surgery is considered if the fracture is displaced, comminuted, or fails to unite (non-union).
  • Early or inadequate immobilization risks delayed healing and long-term dysfunction.

Explanation of other options:

2-3 weeks (Option A): Too short for complete bone healing, especially in a region with poor blood supply like the 5th metatarsal base.

3-5 weeks (Option B): Also inadequate for ensuring solid bone union and may lead to refracture or non-union.

16-20 weeks (Option D): Excessively long for an uncomplicated 5th metatarsal fracture and generally only considered in cases of delayed or non-union.

Reference:

https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22247-fifth-metatarsal-fracture

questions.text: A child presents with growth failure. Biochemical analysis shows normal Ca2+, normal PTH, reduced phosphate, and increased ALP. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypophosphatemic rickets presents with low phosphate, elevated ALP, and normal calcium and PTH, due to defective renal phosphate reabsorption.

  • Hypophosphatemic rickets (especially X-linked) is the most common hereditary cause of rickets.
  • It results from renal phosphate wasting despite normal vitamin D and calcium levels.
  • In these patients:
    • Serum phosphate is low due to proximal renal tubular phosphate loss.
    • Calcium remains normal because intestinal absorption is preserved.
    • PTH is normal or mildly elevated, unlike in nutritional rickets.
    • ALP is elevated due to increased osteoblastic activity during defective bone mineralization.
  • The child presents with growth failure, a key clinical feature.
  • Radiographic features of rickets such as metaphyseal fraying, cupping, and splaying are usually seen.

Explanation of other options:

Nutritional rickets (Option A): PTH is elevated, and calcium is often low or low-normal due to vitamin D deficiency. Also, 25(OH)D is decreased.

Type 1 VDDR (Option C): Caused by 1-alpha hydroxylase deficiency, leading to low 1,25(OH)2D, low calcium and phosphate, elevated PTH, and ALP. It does not show normal calcium and PTH.

Type 2 VDDR (Option D): Due to end-organ resistance to 1,25(OH)2D. Despite normal or elevated 1,25(OH)2D, calcium and phosphate are low, PTH is elevated, and ALP is raised.

questions.text: A heavy lifter presents with lower back ache. Identify the nerve compressed in the following disc prolapse?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

L5 nerve root is the most commonly compressed nerve in lumbar disc prolapse, especially at the L4-L5 level, causing dorsiflexion weakness and pain over the anterolateral leg and dorsum of the foot.

  • Lumbar disc prolapse commonly affects individuals involved in repetitive heavy lifting or strenuous physical activity.
  • In this case:
    • L4-L5 disc prolapse compresses the L5 nerve root.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Lower back pain
    • Radiating leg pain (sciatica) down the lateral thigh, anterolateral leg, and dorsum of the foot
    • Motor weakness: especially of extensor hallucis longus (difficulty lifting the big toe or foot-foot drop)
    • No reflex loss (ankle and knee jerks are typically preserved)
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-Ray : Useful to rule out bony pathology.
    • CT : Reveals disc shape abnormalities, loss of pre-thecal fat, and herniated material pressing on nerve roots or theca.
    • MRI : Gold standard. Clearly shows the prolapsed disc, nerve roots, and thecal sac.
    • Myelography : Useful when CT or MRI is unavailable. Shows dye flow block, indentation, or root cut-off sign in lateral prolapse.

Level-wise Comparison Table:

questions.text: A man presents with back pain following a road traffic accident. There was no history of neurological deficit. X-ray spine is done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The absence of neurological deficits and X-ray findings of isolated posterior element involvement point to a spinous process fracture.

  • Spinous process fractures occur due to direct trauma or hyperextension injuries and involve the posterior bony projection of a vertebra.
  • These fractures are often stable, and because the spinal canal and neural structures remain unaffected, there are usually no neurological deficits.
  • X-ray typically shows a clear fracture line through the spinous process without vertebral body collapse or disruption of alignment.
  • In the context of trauma with localized pain and preserved neurologic function, this diagnosis is most consistent.

Explanation of other options:

Chance fracture (Option B): Horizontal fracture through the vertebra due to flexion-distraction injuries (e.g., seatbelt injury). Often involves the vertebral body and posterior elements, more severe, and commonly associated with neurological deficits.

Fracture of base of vertebrae (Option C): Refers to more generalized vertebral body fractures (e.g., endplate or pedicle); may involve instability or neurological compromise, not limited to the spinous process.

Compressed fracture (Option D): Involves anterior wedging or collapse of the vertebral body, often due to axial loading; may present with vertebral body height loss on imaging-not consistent with isolated spinous process injury.

Reference:

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S073646791630021X

questions.text: A football player sustains a twisting injury to the ankle and knee during a match. There are no bony injuries detected on examination. The examiner is performing the test shown in the image to evaluate knee stability. Which test is being performed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Lachman test is the most sensitive clinical test for diagnosing anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury, performed with the knee flexed to 20-30°.

  • The Lachman test is the gold standard clinical test for ACL integrity, especially in acute injuries like the twisting trauma described here:
  • Position: Patient lies supine, knee flexed to 20-30°.
  • Maneuver: Examiner stabilizes the distal femur with one hand and applies anterior force to the proximal tibia with the other.
  • Positive Test: Excessive anterior translation of the tibia compared to the uninjured leg, usually >5 mm.
  • Significance: Indicates partial or complete ACL tear.
  • Advantage: Preferred over the anterior drawer test because hamstrings are less active in 30° flexion, reducing false negatives.

Explanation of other options:

Posterior drawer for PCL (Option A): Assesses PCL by pushing the tibia posteriorly with the knee at 90°. Not appropriate for suspected ACL injury.

McMurray (Option B): Evaluates meniscal tears, not ligament injuries. Involves rotation of the tibia during knee flexion-extension.

Anterior drawer for ACL (Option D): Also tests the ACL, but less sensitive than the Lachman test due to influence from hamstring tension. Done at 90° flexion.

Reference:

Anterior Cruciate Ligament Knee Injury - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

Lachman Test - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

https://www.jospt.org/doi/pdf/10.2519/jospt.1995.22.6.263

questions.text: Which area is affected by the fracture shown in the given X-ray?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray shows a fracture at the tibial tuberosity, the site of patellar tendon insertion.

  • A tibial tuberosity fracture involves the anterior projection of the proximal tibia where the patellar tendon inserts.
  • It is commonly seen in adolescent males during growth spurts, often following sudden quadriceps contraction, especially during jumping sports.
  • The fracture typically presents with pain, swelling, and inability to extend the knee, and X-ray reveals a fracture at the tibial tuberosity.
  • While Osgood-Schlatter disease affects the same region, it is a chronic overuse condition, not an acute fracture.

Explanation of other options:

Medial epicondyle of tibia (Option B): This is not a commonly fractured area and lies medially near the tibial plateau; its fracture would not correspond with the tibial tuberosity seen on X-ray.

Gerdy's tubercle fracture (Option C): Located laterally on the proximal tibia as the attachment site of the iliotibial band; fractures here are rare and appear on the lateral side of the tibia, not anteriorly.

Osgood-Schlatter disease (Option D): This is a traction apophysitis, not a true fracture, seen in adolescents with chronic anterior knee pain and swelling at the tibial tuberosity, but without acute disruption of bone continuity as in a fracture.

questions.text: Linear growth of bone is disturbed when a fracture occurs in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The epiphyseal plate (growth plate) is the primary site for longitudinal bone growth, and its injury disrupts this growth process.

  • The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate, is a layer of hyaline cartilage located between the epiphysis and metaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents.
  • It plays a critical role in longitudinal bone growth through endochondral ossification.
  • When a fracture occurs at the epiphyseal plate, it can interfere with the process of bone elongation.
  • This may lead to:
    • Growth disturbances
    • Angular deformities
    • Limb length discrepancies
  • These complications are especially concerning in pediatric fractures and are categorized under Salter-Harris classification depending on the severity and location of the fracture.

Parts of Bone and Their Functions

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537199/

questions.text: Identify the amputation shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows an amputation through the tibia and fibula, indicating a below-knee amputation.

  • A below-knee amputation (BKA), or transtibial amputation, involves surgical removal of the leg below the knee joint while preserving the knee.
  • In this procedure, both the tibia and fibula are transected, and the patella and femur are left intact.
  • This allows for better prosthetic control and more energy-efficient ambulation compared to above-knee amputation.
  • The preserved knee joint plays a crucial role in gait biomechanics.
  • BKA is commonly performed for causes like trauma, peripheral vascular disease, diabetes-related complications, or malignancy.
  • The radiographic appearance shows the amputation level clearly involving the mid-to-proximal third of the tibia and fibula.

Explanation of other options:

Above elbow amputation (Option C): Involves amputation through the humerus, removing the forearm and hand, completely unrelated to tibial and fibular anatomy.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546594/#article-17484.s4

questions.text: What is the type of fracture healing you can expect in a fracture treated in a manner shown in the X-ray given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fractures treated with rigid internal fixation heal by primary bone healing, which involves direct remodeling without callus formation.

  • Primary (Direct) Bone Healing occurs when a fracture is anatomically reduced and stabilized with absolute stability, such as with rigid internal fixation (e.g., compression plating).
  • In this process:
    • Osteons (Haversian systems) directly cross the fracture line without forming a callus.
    • Healing occurs via direct remodeling of lamellar bone and cutting cones led by osteoclasts and osteoblasts.
    • Fracture hematoma is disrupted during surgery, preventing endochondral ossification.
    • Healing is slower but results in strong, anatomically aligned bone with minimal deformity.
    • Since no callus forms, X-rays may not show visible signs of healing, making it harder to assess radiologically.
  • This method is often used in diaphyseal fractures of long bones treated surgically with compression plates.

Comparison Table: Primary vs. Secondary Healing

Explanation of other options:

Secondary healing (Option B): Healing occurs via callus formation through endochondral ossification and is typical of fractures treated non-surgically (e.g., casting). It is faster but less precise.

Creeping substitution (Option C): Refers to the gradual replacement of necrotic bone or cartilage with viable lamellar bone during secondary healing; it is a process within indirect healing, not a type itself.

Intramembranous ossification (Option D): A bone formation mechanism where bone develops directly from mesenchymal tissue, typically seen in flat bones like the skull, not a fracture healing type.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with back pain for six months. Her CT scan image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The CT scan shows anterior slippage of a vertebra, characteristic of spondylolisthesis.

  • Spondylolisthesis is the forward displacement of one vertebral body over the one beneath it, most commonly at L5-S1 or L4-L5.
  • It can be caused by degeneration, trauma, congenital defects, or pars interarticularis defects.
  • In this patient, the chronic back pain and the CT scan showing vertebral misalignment point to a likely diagnosis of degenerative spondylolisthesis, which is typical in older adults.
  • In this type, the pars interarticularis remains intact, but instability of facet joints due to osteoarthritis leads to vertebral slippage.
  • This form usually does not cause severe neurological issues but may lead to chronic back pain and spinal canal narrowing.

Explanation of other options:

Paget's disease (Option A): Shows thickened cortical bone, coarsened trabeculae, and a "cotton wool" appearance on imaging. The vertebrae are typically enlarged with mixed lytic and sclerotic changes-findings not seen in this case.

Osteoporosis (Option B): Leads to generalized bone thinning, often with vertebral compression fractures, not anterior vertebral slippage as seen in spondylolisthesis.

Renal osteodystrophy (Option D): Associated with chronic kidney disease; radiological signs include subperiosteal bone resorption, rugger-jersey spine, and osteosclerosis, none of which are suggested by the CT findings here.

questions.text: A patient suffers an inversion injury to the ankle during a football match. Which structure is most likely to get injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured structure in inversion ankle sprains due to its anatomical location and relative weakness among lateral ligaments.

  • The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is part of the lateral ligament complex of the ankle, which also includes the calcaneofibular and posterior talofibular ligaments.
  • It extends from the anterior margin of the lateral malleolus (fibula) to the neck of the talus.
  • During an inversion injury, the foot rolls inward, placing excessive strain on the lateral side of the ankle-especially the ATFL.
  • This ligament is most commonly injured in low ankle sprains, particularly during sports or missteps.
  • Injury Grading:
    • Grade I: Mild stretching
    • Grade II: Partial tear
    • Grade III: Complete rupture
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pain and swelling over the lateral malleolus
    • Positive anterior drawer test
    • Bruising, tenderness, and instability of the ankle joint
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical examination (anterior drawer test)
    • X-rays to rule out fracture
    • MRI for soft tissue injury assessment
  • Treatment:
    • Grades I & II: RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation), bracing, physiotherapy
    • Grade III: May require surgical repair

Explanation of other options:

Tibialis anterior tendon (Option A): Primarily involved in dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot; not typically injured in lateral (inversion) sprains as it lies anterior-medially.

Tibialis posterior tendon (Option B): Supports the medial longitudinal arch and assists in inversion; more commonly injured in medial ankle injuries or overuse, not lateral inversion sprains.

Extensor hallucis longus tendon (Option C): Involved in extension of the big toe and dorsiflexion; lies on the anterior ankle and is not subjected to strain during inversion.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459212/

questions.text: Which of the following fractures can cause a deformity as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Supracondylar fractures commonly lead to malunion, resulting in a cubitus varus ("gunstock") deformity, especially in children.

  • A supracondylar fracture of the humerus typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) and is the most common elbow fracture in children.
  • When improperly treated or if healing occurs with malalignment, it leads to cubitus varus deformity, also known as "gunstock deformity"-a medial deviation of the extended forearm.
  • This is a result of malunion, not growth plate arrest.
  • These fractures occur just above the condyles of the humerus and can have various displacements including posterior tilt and medial shift, which, if not corrected properly, can misalign the carrying angle.
  • Types:
    • Type I: Undisplaced
    • Type II: Displaced anterior cortex
    • Type III: Completely displaced
  • Complications include:
    • Early: Brachial artery injury, anterior interosseous nerve injury
    • Late: Cubitus varus, Volkmann's ischemia, elbow stiffness
  • Displacements:
    • The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by
      • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
      • Posterior Tilt
      • Proximal shift
      • Medial shift/ Tilt
      • Internal rotation
  • X-ray Findings:
    • Three bony parts of the relationship are maintained.
    • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads
    • Disturbed tear drop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.
    • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.
    • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

Explanation of other options:

Lateral condyle of humerus fracture (Option A): May lead to cubitus valgus deformity, not cubitus varus. Also associated with tardy ulnar nerve palsy.

Monteggia fracture (Option B): Involves fracture of the proximal ulna with radial head dislocation, causing elbow instability, not a gunstock deformity.

Shaft of humerus fracture (Option D): Commonly associated with radial nerve injury and wrist drop, but not with angular deformities of the elbow like cubitus varus.
